name: Mixed Bag 38 Quiz | Mixed 10 Q. Tough [E] | 10 Questions

questions.text: Who wrote the song 'I'm Just Wild About Harry'?
questions.explanation:
Eubie Blake.

	He wrote it in the ragtime era which also gave us such composers as Scott Joplin, Thomas Turpin and James Scott.

questions.text: What was the telephone on the 1950's 'Strike It Rich' called?
questions.explanation:
Heart Line.

	It was a sob show about poor people with their tales of why they wanted to strike it rich. It was hosted by Warren Hull.

questions.text: Name the 'Hamlet' character whose last words were 'The drink, I am poisoned'?
questions.explanation:
Gertrude.

	Gertrude was played in the 1948 film by Eileen Herlie. Hamlet was played by Laurence Olivier.

questions.text: Can you name the host of TV's 'Amateur Hour' that was once a professional musician?
questions.explanation:
Ted Mack.

	He was born in Colorado in 1904 and took over the show when Major Bowes died.

questions.text: Which of the following is a flower?
questions.explanation:
Dahlia.

	It was originally a yellow disk with scarlet rays. They have been hybridized to every shade but blue.

questions.text: What was country comedienne Minnie Pearl's one word greeting?
questions.explanation:
Howdy.

	She was from the mythical town of Grinders Switch, Tennessee and was known for her signature {$1.98} straw hat.

questions.text: They call a pen point a nib, true or false?
questions.explanation:
True.

	It is defined as a projected pointed part. It is also the beak of a bird.

questions.text: With what sport would you associate Suzanne Lenglen?
questions.explanation:
Tennis.

	She was the 1925 Women's Singles Champion.

questions.text: How many did Jesus feed with the loaves and fishes?
questions.explanation:
5000.

	John 6:1-13. Five loaves of bread and two small fishes.

questions.text: What group did Jeff Beck start with?
questions.explanation:
Yardbirds.

	Chris Dreja, Keith Relf, and Jim McCartney were also members. Eric Clapton was with them before his move to the Blues Breakers.
